author: SirGlass
body:
The target date fund is a nice set it and forget it I would check the expense ratio and also what its current allocation is, sometimes target date funds are too conservative for some people (hold more bonds than they want to) however they are still usually pretty good options

The other thing would be just to construct your own so you can allocate how you want to. I like the classic 3 fund portfolio  however because they do not have a total USA market fund you would have to do something like (NOte these are just sample allocations you can allocate how you want)

Fidelity 500 Index Fund 45%

Fidelity Mid Cap Index Fund 10%

Fidelity Small Cap Index Fund 5%

Fidelity Total International Index Fund 20%

Fidelity US Bond Index Fund 20%

Note some people skip bonds before they are close to retirement or only like to hold 10-15% bonds

author: Loadingexperience
body:
The problem is that RH takes the money, lets say 50$ for GME share, routes that order to Citadel for PFOF. Citadel internalise that order and shits out and IOU for you. 

All good so far right?

But Citadel as MM dont like to cover during major volatility so they keep taking these 50/60/70..$ orders while internalising order flow from RH or other PFOF broker(basically assuming short position), they know from experience that 99.99% of the time markets will calm down, the price will drop and they will be able to secure shares for favorable price to deliver them. PLEASE LET ME CLEAR THAT MOST OF THE TIME ITS DONE UNWILLINGLY BY ALGOS THAT RUN THE MARKET.

So what happened is that when GME started blowing  up at December/Early January algos took these 20/30/40$ orders gave out IOUs but never delivered actual shares. By mid Jan, some1 got margin call and realised that GME situation is that 00.01% event and now they are on the hook for 2700% payout compared to what they took in. 

Thats why only PFOF brokers had to turn off buy button, because unlike brokers like fidelity that actually got their shares delivered they only had IOU but not the share and as soon as some1 pressed Sell button they had to pay from their own pocket the difference hence all the liquidity issues.

author: emikoala
body:
Target date is a safe place to stash your money. The Fidelity indexes are good because their expense ratios are typically 0.01-0.02% since a computer is doing all the work instead of a human investment advisor. Higher expense ratios aren't necessarily bad if the human-operated fund beats the computer-operated fund by a large enough margin, but that happens less often than you might think.

I'm a relatively risk averse person who nonetheless understands that the optimal amount of risk is not zero, so my investing paradigm is to invest more in lower-risk ventures and less in higher-risk ones.

My retirement savings are roughly:

* 28% target-date fund (pre-tax account)
* 22% Fidelity 500 (pre-tax account)
* 17% Fidelity Mid Cap (pre-tax account)
* 13% Fidelity Small Cap (pre-tax account)
* 20% speculative investments in a slew of stocks with high growth potential (post-tax account)

Your mix could look different depending on your own risk tolerance, but for my 2c it helps steel my nerves enough to take the bigger swings like in my post-tax account if I'm only swinging with a small percentage of my savings and the majority of it is in a safer place. There's always a trade-off between risk and reward, you will need to find the sweet spot where you feel most comfortable. At some point you may realize you're not comfortable with as much risk as you thought, and at some point you may realize that you'd be comfortable with more risk, and you can change your 401k allocations along the way to match your comfort level.

author: DeFi_ance
body:
I recently switched over to Yubikey after using Authy for years, and I friggin' love it. It's far more secure and it's even quicker than pulling up an OTP code for sites that support the FIDO protocol directly, such as Coinbase and Gemini. For sites that don't support FIDO and still use OTP (what Authy/Google Auth is), Yubikey can do those too with a Yubico Authenicator app which requires your key to generate the codes.

Yubico's site has excellent setup guides and FAQs to get things going. The only downside is the expense, as you want to buy multiple keys to have a backup incase you lose your primary. But, if you've got a decent chunk of money to protect, spending a hundred bucks for a couple Yubikeys is well worth the vastly improved security.

TradFi is so behind crypto on security models, it's insane. For Fidelity, TDA, and my three banks, they *all* only have SMS 2FA as an option, not even OTP. And for my trading platform, ThinkOrSwim, it doesn't have any 2FA at all to login and make trades. Drives me nuts.

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
"if not they are making money another way."

That's exactly it! They make money another way, by offering additional financial planning services, from margin, and from options.

By providing a high quality trading platform that is totally free, and has market-leading price improvements since they don't use PFOF, they create trust advertise their other services.

Fidelity is trusted, and that is an important point.

author: lyleberrycrunch
body:
Yeah unfortunately for most blue-collar folks that’s how it is. It’s big finance and it’s confusing and most working families don’t know if they can trust it. But that’s mostly because they haven’t seen the historical data (hundreds of years of it). And they tend to draw a false equivalency between options trading/gambling and dollar-cost-averaging into VT or VTI

I think a lot of it comes from accessibility and family influence: back in the day it used to cost a bunch of money to trade and it was super hard to do so most didn’t even bother. And if your parents don’t know anything about stocks, they won’t teach you. I was lucky in that I grew up in a very stock-friendly household with CNBC going 24/7. I was aware of the market in elementary school lol but I recognize this isn’t how most people grew up

Anyways, yeah there’s usually no need for financial advisors. Odds are they’ll get complicated, try to get fees out of you and whatever they tell you will probably underperform VT or VTI anyway. Great choice with Fidelity by the way, they’re an excellent broker. And even if you lost money giving into the hype on CLOV, hopefully you can consider it a cheap “intro to the stock market course” because at least it got you more involved

Also, just want to mention that there’s probably no need to own VTI and VT/VXUS. If you already own all 3, I wouldn’t bother selling though. Basically VTI is total US stock market, VT is total all stock market and VXUS is total non-US stock market so VT is just a combination of VTI/VXUS. Currently it’s about 62% VTI and 38% VXUS because of the size of the US market but it’s up to you how much you want to weight international. I tend to go less as I have a bit of a preference toward US stocks so I like the weighting you currently have

And yeah, I still check my brokerage app way too often but oh well. Just don’t ever panic sell even if the market crashes and try not to act on emotion. I remember people selling when the market was down 7-10% per day during March 2020, thinking they’d buy back later, meanwhile I bought the entire time and the market rallied extremely quickly. Some are still waiting on the sidelines hoping they’ll get the correction they were hoping for. Just remember the two key phrases “more money has been lost trying to anticipate corrections than lost in the corrections themselves” and “time in the market beats timing the market”

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
From their website.

I simply looked up the stock most people who recommend them are investing in, and it has a 5% reinvestment fee.

I'm sure you can find stocks on there without a reinvestment fee. Instead of not paying any fees, across the board, as I do, you pay varying fees depending on which stock you buy.

It also has  $5 one-time investment fee, and a $2.50 recurring fee. Every time you trade there is a surcharge. Plus $.05 per share!

What is the case for not "trusting" Fidelity? I understand the case for not trusting PFOF and trading apps, but those aren't the only brokerage options.
